publicationStmt.p: Originally published between 1740, November 7 and 1814, February 23.

sourceDesc.p:
Digitized and published online using the viewer developed by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft via:
https://kurzelinks.de/0ayo

text.body:
Our late brother George Henry Loskiel, bishop
of the Church of the Bretheren, and intended member
of the Helper-Department in the Unity’s Elders Confe-
rence, who departed happily to our Lord on the
23 Feb. 1814, has left the following account of
his course of life.
“I was born the 7 Nov. 1740 at Angermünde in
Courland, where my father was a faithful
minister of the gospel till his happy departure
out of time the 12 Aug. 1780. My mother, whose maiden
name was Hoffman, was a native of Levonia.
I shall thank these my dear parents in eternity, for
their having provided for me, the best and most
carful education.
Nothing remarkable occurred to me in my youth-
ful years, except what our Saviour effected on my
heart in stillness by his Spirit, for which I shall
thank & praise his rich mercy, when I shall have
the grace to see & adore him in heaven.
In the year 1748 B. John Hüffel arrived from one
of the cong.ns in Germany, as private tutor in my father’s
house, & remained there till the years 1759; when I,
agreeable to permission previously obtained to reside
in cong.n of the bretheren, traveled in his company,
by
by way of Sweden, to Barby, where we arrived on the
5 July the same year. On the 26 Dec. I was received
into the church, & on the 30 Sept. 1760 partook with
the same for the first time of the holy sacrament.
During this period, from the year 1748 till 1760,
I made various experiences, whiconcerning which I could
say much to the praise & glory of our dear Lord. I was
at various times under severe temptations from unbelief,
from which I was most mercifully delivered by the
perseverance of my soul. The good providence of God,
in various cases, evidently watched over me, to preserve
me from instant death. Once I fell into a large kettle
of boiling water; & another time into a cistern of cold
water. On acertain occasion, a person in a most violent
rage, threw a short-pointed knife at my uncle; it
missed him, but struck & almost killed me. In my
19th year I was thrown from a horse, & the circumstan-
ces were such, that it was a wonder to every one
that my life had been preserved. For every such
deliverance that is known or shall be to me, my songs of
praise shall be raised before the throne of the
Lamb.
My heart remained during all this time,
amidst innumerable changes, under a great preserve,
though
though the reading of the four Evangelists, & particularly
the history of the sufferings of our Saviour, caused me
many serious reflections. Once on retiring to sleep, after
meditating much on the subject, our Lord in his suffering,
was presented to my mind in a dream, in the most
lively manner. This occasioned, for a short time after-
wards, a happy feeling in my heart; but I was soon
after conscious, that I was still as unconverted, and
full of unbelief, as ever I had been before. Our Saviour
at length revealed himself to me as the Reconciler of
my soul, & bestowed upon me that grace which makes
me happy, & will continue to be my happiness till
I shall see him face to face.
In Barby I studied divinity & medicine. In the
latter I practiced with good success till I resolved
to devote myself to the service of our dear Lord,
to be used in the ministry of the gospel as he might
think proper, without making any particular plan for
myself, & only having this principle in view, that he
might be with me in every thing.
In Sept. 1765 I received my first call in the
service of the Brns. Church, as a teacher in the Pedago-
gium at Niesky. In 1766 I was called to Neuwied
& in 1768 to Marienborn in Wetteraviaa, as a minister of the church
and
and laborer of the ferigle brethren. I was called to the same offices at
Amsterdam in Holland, I was calledat the synod in
1769. On the 27 June 1771 I entered into the married
state with the single sister Mary Magdalene Barlach; &
we lived happily together as before the Lord, in the sense
of our faults & imperfections, & of his rich mercy. Soon
after, we were called to Zeist, where I officiated for
B. Henry von Breeiningk three quarters of a year. From
here we moved to Kleinwelke, where I served as
cong. Helper & minister, & with my wife as the laborers
of the mar.d bon. & fri., from 1775 to 1781; when I went
to Barby, by way of Carlsbad, where I endeavored to
preach the gospel among the Roman catholics. At the
general Synod of the Bretheren’s Unity in the year 1782
I had the favor to be present, and was called by the
same to be general. Helper in Livonia. Afterwards, in
addition to this charge, I was appointed agent to the
imperiof the Bretherens Unity to the imperial court
at St. Petersburg, & the minister of the Brns. Church
therein that city. The nature of my office in Livonia obliged
me to travel very much. At the general synod in
1789, I was called to be cong.n helper, & laborer of
the married choir in Gnadenfrey. Here I witnessed
the great fire, which almost consumed that place, &
saw
saw it rebuild again. In 1794 I was called to
discharge the same offices in Niesky; & in 1798
came as cong.n helper to Herrenhuth. Here I remained
till 1802, having been called by the Synod in 1801 to
N. America, to the service of the work of God generally
that is committed to the care of the Bretheren there, & as
cong.n helper & minister at Bethlehem. On the 23 July
the same year, my wife & I arrived in Bethlehem,
after a prosperous journey both by land and sea. Here
I am at the time of writing this, in expectation whether
my dear Lord will soon permit me to rest from my
labors, or strengthen me anew for his service.
I need not here notice, that I have purposely
omitted the mention of many particular occurrences
in which I have been concerned in so many different places.
When I reflect on them all, I adore my gracious
Lord in the dust for all the proofs of his mercy,
for his patience, for his constant forgiveness, and
for his mere than tender love, with which he has
carried me, the poorest of his sheep, in his bosom.”
So far his own account
His widow adds as follows:
On the 29 Decbr. 1810 my dear husband was called
by the Unity’s Elders Conference from his offices here,
& to return to Europe. He had for some time before,
found
found his official duties to press too hard upon hism
mind; as ever since his arrival in this country, his
strength had been declining. In May following we
travelled with B: V. h. Van Vleckto Litiz, where, by com-
mission from the Unity’s Elders Conference, with the
assistance of B: Charles Gotthold Reichel, he consecrated
B: John Herbst to be a bishop of the Brethren’s church.
This solemn transaction was accompanied with the
particular power & grace of our Lord. On our return
to Bethlehem, he resigned his offices of president of
the Genl. Helps. Confe. for the Pennsylvania & adjacent
congns., & cong(?). helper & minister in Bethlehem, to B: Chals.
Gotthold Reichel. He found his infirmities now fast
increasing; his leg in particular evere afflicted with
sores, & he was during the following winter entirely
confined to the house. On the 2 June 1813, he was
seized with a violent fever, which for a time depri-
ved him of speech, & tended much to debilitate his
constitution. His pains in different parts of his
body evere now often excessive, & called forth the
tears of sympathy of those who visited him. He
remained uniformly friendly & affectionate to every
one, only he was sorry that speaking was difficult to
him. He was never impatient, even after sleepless
nights
nights; but constantly expressed thankfulness to our
Lord for his gracious assistance, & precious nearness,
through which he said all his afflictions were lightened.
He used often to say: “How graciously does our dear
“Saviour deal with me!”
In Septr. a pain in his side made it difficult
for him to lie in bed, & his faculties suffered through
severe head-ache. During the last month of his life
he suffered extremely, especially through a sore on his
back. But his patience continued uninterrupted,
and he comforted himself with the thought, that all
the troubles of this life would soon be changed for
unutterable joys, when he should see & be with his
Saviour for ever. He had for many years earnestly
desired after this happiness, and was never tired
of meditating on the subject, what that implied:
“to have the living hope, after having run the race
“of faith, to see his Saviour as He is.” It was parti-
cularly pleasing to him, that brethren & sisters often
sung verses in his chamber, accompanied with music;
those hymns were most agreeable & interesting to him,
which treat of our departure to the Lord, and of the
church made perfect. On the 23 Feb., as his weakness
had for many some days much encreased, it was
observed
observed to him that he would soon attain the great object of all
his wishes at which he smiled. In the afternoon at 5 o’clock, as it was
evident that the time of his departure was very near,
the ble[s]sing of the Lord and the church was imparted
to him, during a particular sense of the divine presence,
and our fellowship with the church triumphant.
Soon after, he fell softly asleep, & his dear redeemed
soul went into the arms of his Redeemer.
I rejoice (continues Sister Loskiel), at the happy
lot of my dear, now eternally bleſsed husband,
whom I esteemed as a precious jewel given me for
a time by our Lord. His conversation and whole
department was bleſsed to me. His tenderneſs,
affection & patience towards me, & especially his
attachment to our Lord & Saviour, whom he loved
above all things, I shall never forget. I cannot
but feel his loſs very sensibly; but he is now
for ever happy, & rests from all his labors.”
The congregation at Bethlehem acknowledges,
with thankfulneſs to our Lord, the bleſsings they
have received, through the faithful services of our
late brother, for about 9 years, in the ministry
among them; & wishes him a rich reward of grace.
As
As he concluded his own account of his course
through life with observing, that he has purposely
omitted the mention of many particular occurrences in
which he was concerned in different places, we will
also paſs them over in silence, only noticing generally,
that the wish which he expreſsed on his entrance into
the service of our Lord, that He might be with
him in every thing he undertook, has been signally
granted him. He preached the death of the Lord in
every place wither he was called, with a warm
heart & with remarkable bleſsing. Without doubt
he finds now that wish of his gratified, that he
meets now before the throne of the Lamb many of
those to whom he declared the gospel with bleſsing.
In our hymn-book we have many pleasing
memorials of his poetical genius, which also prove
his heavenlymindedne[s]s, & how his heart delighted
to mediate on the sufferings & merits of our
Redeemer.
Our Lord was pleased to lay a particular bleſ-
sing on his two principal works: “the history of the
miſsion of the United Brethren among the Indians
in N. America”; & “Something for the heart on the
way to eternity”. [ The former only of these has been
translated
translated into English ].
It was a distinguished trait of his character,
to “rejoice with them that do rejoice, & weep with them
that weep”. To assist the poor, to do good, was his
heart’s delight; & he was often sorry, that he could
not do herein as much as he wished.
It is still to be remarked, that he was ordained
a deacon in Zeist on the 22 May 1768, & a presbyter
in Barby on the 19 March 1775; & before his journey
from Herrenhuth to America, on the 14 March 1802,
he was consecrated by B. John Fred. Reichel to be a
Bishop of the Brethren’s church.
As already noticed, his constellation seems to have
been impaired by the journey to this country. Yet he
entered with activity; & in reliance upon the powerful
assistance of our dear Lord, upon the office committed
to him here, which in the sequel however often
seemed too hard for him, & to depress his spirits.
in the year 1803 he had the particular pleasure
to visit the Indian mission at Goshen on the Mus-
kingum, which was so much the more agreeable to
him, as through his publication of the history of the
mission of the brethren among them, his affection
for them fo was very great, & they were a particular
object
object of his prayers before our Lord.
He visited also, to mutual satisfaction, all the
churches of the brethren which are under the care of
the general helpers conference; & his remembrance memory among
them all is blessed.
After that, as mentioned above, he was called by
the Unity’s elders conference to Europe; he prepared
himself for the journey. But on account of the war
he felt no freedom to undertake it, which occasioned
him much concern. It was therefore encouraging to
him to learn towards the close of the year 1811, that
he was called to be cong.n helper in Gnadenfrey.
But in the mean time his health had much declined,
he did not however give up the hope of being able
to make the journey, which continued to be the case
when on the 30 May 1812, he received a call
from the Unity’s elders conference, to be a member
of the late B. Jeremy Reisler. He rejoiced, with un-
feigned loneliness of heart, at the gracious views of
our Lord with him; & the cong.n at Bethlehem,
& all the cong.m here, took a near share in his joy,
& very sincerely wished that, agreeable to this
call, he might be able to make the journey to
Europe.
On account of frequent sickneſs, & his weakly state
of body, this became however more & more impro-
bable, & both he and we could at length not think
otherwise, than that our Lord through this call
would only make known that he was satisfied with
hios willingneſs merely to devote himself with body
and soul to his further service. His beloved colleagues
in the Unity’s elders conference he remembered often
with great feruency [frequency?] in his prayers, & wished them in
the execution of their office in the present critical
times, particularly in Europe, that our Lord might
powerfully support them. He was for sorry for the
interruption of the correspondence with them through
the war.
When his weakneſs so encreased, as to prevent
his taking any further active share in the work of
the Lord, he remained instant in prayer both by
day & night for its furtherance & prosperity, and
especially in the Unity of the Brethren.
But his principal concern was, that he him-
self, with reference to that happy departure out
of time, which he earnestly longed for, was daily,
as a poor sinner, cleansed in the blood of Jesus.-
Now, clothed upon with the blood & righteousneſs
of
of his Redeemer, he writes in songs of praises
with the church triumphant, bringing praise,
honor & glory to the Lamb that was slain.
The Time of his pilgrimage here below lasted
73 years, 3 months & 16 days.
At a lovefeast of the congr. in Bethlehem,
which was held on the 27 Feb. 1814, to the memory
of our much beloved brother Georg Henry
Loskiel, the following texts of scripture were sung
musically from the orchestra:
“Blessed are the dead which die in the Lord
from henceforth: Yea, [?] saith [?] the Spirit, that they
may rest from their labor; & their works do follow
them.” Rev. 14.13
“The ransomed of the Lord shall return, and
come to Zion with songs, and everlasting joy upon
their heads: they shall obtain joy and glandess;
and sorrow and sighing shall flee away.” Js. 35.10.
And the following verses were sung by the congr.
“O what joy, :||:
O what joy awaiteth me!
I rejoice in expectation,
That I in my flesh shall see
Him, the God of my salvation,
And behold the Lord in endle[s]s bli[s]s,
As he is ://:
Yea, Amen! ://:
Pardon’d Sinners here rejoice
In this hope and consolation,
That we shall with sweeter voice,
Sing in the great congregation,
Thou, O Lamb, hast brought us nigh to God
By thy blood! ://:
